fact: The highest mountain known to man is the Olympus Mons on Mars. It rises three times higher than Earth's highest mountain, Mount Everest, whose peak is 5.5 miles above sea level.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth. That's at least a billion trillion!
The sunset on Mars appears blue.
Mercury & Venus are the only 2 planets in our solar system that have no moons.
The hottest planet in our solar system is Venus.
Our solar system is 4.57 billion years old.
A light-year is the distance covered by light in a single year. So one light-year equates to roughly 5,903,026,326,255 miles!
Earth is the only planet not named after a God.

'The Unicorn' is closest known black hole to Earth. It is roughly three times the mass of our sun. A luminous star called a red giant orbits with the black hole in a so-called binary star system named V723 Mon.

In 2019, astronomers of the Event Horizon Telescope captured the first ever image of a supermassive black hole (M87) which was located at the centre of a galaxy Messier 87 (M87). This black hole is calculated to be 6.5 billion times the Sun's mass and is 55 million light years away from the Earth.
According to mathematics, white holes are possible, although as of yet we have found none.
Enceladus, one of Saturn’s smaller moons, reflects 90% of the Sun’s light.
The Whirlpool Galaxy (M51) was the first celestial object identified as being spiral.
Uranus’ blue glow is due to the gases in its atmosphere.
Neptune’s moon, Triton, orbits the planet backwards.
Stars twinkle because of the way light is disrupted as it passes through Earth’s atmosphere.
Using the naked eye, you can see 3 – 7 different galaxies from Earth.
The closest galaxy to us is the Andromeda Galaxy – it’s estimated at 2.5 million light-years away.
The distance between the Sun & Earth is defined as an Astronomical Unit.
The first artificial satellite in space was called 'Sputnik'.
Exoplanets are planets that orbit around other stars.

There are 5 Dwarf Planets recognized in our Solar System.
Halley’s Comet will pass over Earth again on July 26, 2061. The famous comet was last seen on February 9, 1986, and only orbits the Earth once every 75 – 76 years.
Scientists define the beginning of interstellar space as the place where the Sun’s constant flow of material and magnetic field stop affecting its surroundings. This place is called the heliopause.
